questions.explanation: Premeditated means thought out or planned beforehand. The opposite is **unplanned**, meaning done without prior arrangement or thought.

questions.question: A [tentative] solution was provided.
questions.explanation: Tentative means not certain or fixed; provisional. The opposite is **a definitive** solution, meaning one that is final, conclusive, and clearly defined.

questions.question: The chief said he would use the power [inherent] in his office to stop the celebration.
questions.explanation: Inherent means existing in something as a permanent, essential, or characteristic attribute (common to). The opposite is **unrelated to**, meaning having no connection with.

questions.question: In our last play, Segun acted the [hero].
questions.explanation: A hero is a person admired for courage or noble qualities; the main good character. The opposite is **villain**, meaning the main evil character.

questions.question: The police found [conclusive] proof of the boy's guilt.
questions.explanation: Conclusive means serving to prove a case; decisive or convincing (corroborative, incriminating). The opposite is **a doubtful** proof, meaning uncertain or questionable.

questions.question: The point you have made is quite [apt].
questions.explanation: Apt means appropriate or suitable in the circumstances (helpful). The opposite is **irrelevant**, meaning not connected with or relevant to something.

questions.question: The man drew a sword as people [congregated] round him.
questions.explanation: To congregate means to gather into a crowd or mass (gathered round, mobbed). The opposite is **fled from**, meaning ran away from.

questions.question: The notice reads, 'No cash [transactions] in this hall.'
questions.explanation: Transactions refers to a business deal or action, especially an exchange of money. In the context of 'No cash transactions', the implied opposite form of payment is a **Cheque**, as it is an alternative to cash.

questions.question: Sola is [apathetic] about his work.
questions.explanation: Apathetic means showing or feeling no interest, enthusiasm, or concern (indifferent, bored). The opposite is **enthusiastic**, meaning having or showing intense and eager enjoyment, interest, or approval.

questions.question: The members of the family have a [hasty] breakfast before starting out on their journey.
questions.explanation: Hasty means done with excessive speed or urgency (hurried). The opposite is **leisurely**, meaning done or acting in a relaxed, unhurried way.

questions.question: The [poverty] level among the masses is unbearable.
questions.explanation: Poverty means the state of being extremely poor. The opposite is **affluence**, meaning the state of having a great deal of money; wealth.

questions.question: The chairman was accused of implementing policies that favoured the [elite].
questions.explanation: The elite are a select group that is superior in terms of abilities or wealth (executives). The opposite is the **oppressed**, meaning those subject to harsh and authoritarian treatment; the disadvantaged.

questions.question: The manager was impressed by the man's [eagerness].
questions.explanation: Eagerness means enthusiasm to do or to have something. The opposite is **indifference**, which is a lack of interest, concern, or enthusiasm.

questions.question: He is known for making [threadbare] arguments as a scholar.
questions.explanation: Threadbare (of an argument) means overused or worn out; lacking originality or substance (baseless, empty). The opposite is **justifiable**, meaning able to be shown to be right or reasonable; valid and substantial.

questions.question: The lecturer's [obscure] publications counted against him during the promotion exercise.
questions.explanation: Obscure means not discovered or known about; uncertain (closed, restricted). The opposite is **widespread**, meaning found or distributed over a large area.

questions.question: The man found his wife physically [repellant].
questions.explanation: Repellant means driving away or disagreeable (unpleasant). The opposite is **attractive**, meaning pleasing or appealing to the senses.

questions.question: As an [absolute] ruler, Adayi books no opposition from his subordinates.
questions.explanation: An absolute ruler has total power (despotic dictator). The opposite political figure is typically **a magnanimous democrat**, who is generous and forgiving, and rules according to the will of the people.

questions.question: The response to the advertisement has been [phenomenal].
questions.explanation: Phenomenal means highly remarkable, extraordinary, or impressive. The opposite is **unimpressive**, meaning not producing a strong or favourable effect.

questions.question: My father lived a [spartan] life before his death.
questions.explanation: Spartan means simple, frugal, or austere. The opposite is **luxurious**, meaning extremely comfortable or elegant, especially when involving great expense.

questions.question: Bola’s parents went through an [acrimonious] divorce.
questions.explanation: Acrimonious means bitter or sharp in temper or manner (bitter, sour). The opposite is **a peaceful** or friendly separation.

questions.question: Iliya’s account of the incident is [appalling].
questions.explanation: Appalling means causing shock or dismay; horrific. The opposite is **fascinating**, meaning extremely interesting or engaging.

questions.question: She [encapsulated] her view of the nature of life in a poem.
questions.explanation: To encapsulate means to express the essential features of (something) briefly and concisely (summed up). The opposite is to **expatiated on**, which means to speak or write in detail about a subject.

questions.question: We were held [spellbound] by his eloquence.
questions.explanation: Spellbound means having one's attention fully held by something (impressed). The opposite is **unimpressed**, meaning not feeling any admiration or interest.

questions.question: We had difficulty eating the meat because it was [leathery].
questions.explanation: Leathery means tough and chewy (tough, stringy). The opposite is **tender**, meaning easy to cut or chew.

questions.question: The boy is too [indolent] to do well at school.
questions.explanation: Indolent means lazy or disinclined to exert oneself (inactive, slothful). The opposite is **industrious**, meaning diligent and hardworking.

questions.question: Salasi’s [tremendous] efforts have yielded results.
questions.explanation: Tremendous means extremely large or great. The opposite is **insignificant**, meaning too small or unimportant to be worthy of consideration.

questions.question: The [computerized] service of the new banks is heart-warming.
questions.explanation: Computerized service is automated and performed by a machine. The opposite is **Manual** service, which is done by hand or human effort.

questions.question: Life has become a [misery] for many owing to the harsh economic condition.
questions.explanation: Misery means a state or feeling of great distress or discomfort (drudgery). The opposite is **comfort**, meaning a state of physical ease and well-being.

questions.question: The company director has a [vivacious] personality.
questions.explanation: Vivacious means attractively lively and animated (gregarious). The opposite is **a dull** personality.

questions.question: Young people have a [penchant] for fast cars.
questions.explanation: Penchant means a strong or habitual liking for something (likeness, passion). The opposite is **dislike**, meaning a feeling of distaste or hostility.

questions.question: Most of his latest actions are [militant] in nature.
questions.explanation: Militant means aggressively active in support of a cause (zealous, passionate). The opposite is **civil**, meaning relating to ordinary citizens and their concerns, often implying non-aggression or politeness.

questions.question: His ideas sounded quite palatable yet they were [jettisoned] by the group.
questions.explanation: To jettison means to abandon or discard something (dumped, denied). The opposite is **accepted**, meaning to agree to take or recognize.

questions.question: The compulsory leave made her feel [listless].
questions.explanation: Listless means lacking energy or enthusiasm. The opposite is **energetic**, meaning possessing or exhibiting great energy.

questions.question: A novel is an [embellished] falsehood, said the teacher.
questions.explanation: Embellished means made more attractive by adding decorative details (adorned) or, in the context of a story, by adding fictional details (exaggerated). The best fit among the options is **obliterated** which means destroyed or wiped out, suggesting the removal of the added details.

questions.question: I have had enough of your [impudence].
questions.explanation: Impudence means the quality of being impertinent or disrespectful; arrogance, boldness, incivility. The opposite is **politeness**, meaning the quality of being respectful and considerate.

questions.question: We were [collectively] responsible for keeping the machine in good shape.
questions.explanation: Collectively means as a group; jointly. The opposite is **severally**, meaning individually or separately.

questions.question: His comment was not [printable].
questions.explanation: Not printable means unsuitable for publication, usually because it is obscene or offensive. The opposite is **suitable**, meaning right or appropriate for the purpose.

questions.question: [Curiously], he escaped unhurt.
questions.explanation: Curiously means strangely or surprisingly (oddly). The opposite is **Normally**, meaning usually or typically.

questions.question: The teacher said that Ali’s essay was full of many [redundant] details.
questions.explanation: Redundant means no longer needed or useful; superfluous (surplus, excessive). The opposite is **Necessary**, meaning required to be done, or essential.

questions.question: His father [surmounted] the myriad of obstacles on his way.
questions.explanation: To surmount means to overcome or conquer (overcame, conquered). The opposite is **Failed** to overcome.

questions.question: Her [ingenuous] smile drew our attention.
questions.explanation: Ingenuous means innocent and unsuspecting (candid, simple). The opposite is **Artful**, meaning clever or cunning, often implying a lack of sincerity.

questions.question: Ndeni gave a [flawless] speech at the party.
questions.explanation: Flawless means without any blemishes or imperfections (perfect, faultless). The opposite is **Faltering**, meaning hesitating or losing strength, implying imperfections or errors.

questions.question: Beneath Ado’s [gruff] exterior, he’s really very kind-hearted.
questions.explanation: Gruff means rough or surly in manner (harsh, rough, impolite). The opposite is **Mild**, meaning gentle and not severe or harsh.

questions.question: The captain says sports is being [debased] by commercial sponsorship.
questions.explanation: To debase means to reduce in quality or value; degrade (lowered, corrupted). The opposite is **Exalted**, meaning to raise in rank, power, or character; to glorify.

questions.question: Governing a country is not always as [straightforward] as people sometimes imagine.
questions.explanation: Straightforward means uncomplicated and easy to understand (simple, easy). The opposite is **Complicated**, meaning consisting of many interconnected parts or elements; intricate.

questions.question: The crowd was very [receptive] to the speaker’s suggestion.
questions.explanation: Receptive means willing to consider or accept new ideas or suggestions (amenable, responsive). The opposite is **Hostile**, meaning showing or feeling opposition or dislike.

questions.question: There was a general [acquiescence] on the new drug law.
questions.explanation: Acquiescence means the reluctant acceptance of something without protest (agreement, consent). The opposite is **Resistance**, meaning the refusal to accept or comply with something.

questions.question: Aisha seems to feel [ambivalent] about her future.
questions.explanation: Ambivalent means having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something (uncertain, indecisive). The opposite is **Decisive**, meaning settling an issue or producing a definite result.

questions.question: The report of the committee contained a [plethora] of details.
questions.explanation: Plethora means a large or excessive amount of something (plenty, surplus, excess). The opposite is **Scarcity**, meaning the state of being scarce or in short supply.

questions.question: The weather was still very heavy and [sultry].
questions.explanation: Sultry means hot and humid (oppressive, sweltering). The opposite is **Cool**, meaning of a relatively low temperature.

questions.question: Ada gave her husband a look that made words [superfluous].
questions.explanation: Superfluous means unnecessary, especially through being more than enough (redundant, excessive). The opposite is **Necessary**, meaning required to be done, or essential.

questions.question: The warring communities were [coerced] into negotiating a settlement.
questions.explanation: To coerce means to persuade an unwilling person to do something by using force or threats (forced, compelled, threatened). The opposite is **Persuaded**, which is to convince someone to do something through reasoning or argument.

questions.question: His father served as a [mercenary] in the army.
questions.explanation: A mercenary is a professional soldier hired to serve in a foreign army. The opposite of someone fighting for money is a **Patriot**, who fights for the love of their country.

questions.question: Jummai is [cruel] to her husband.
questions.explanation: Cruel means wilfully causing pain or suffering to others (wicked, harsh, brutal). The opposite is **Kind**, meaning friendly, generous, and considerate.

questions.question: The teacher who beat the student was treated with [mercy].
questions.explanation: Mercy means compassion or forgiveness shown toward someone whom it is within one's power to punish or harm (leniency, pity). The opposite is **Cruelty**, meaning a cruel action or quality.

questions.question: His wife hates his [garrulous] attitude.
questions.explanation: Garrulous means excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters (talkative, loquacious, chatty). The opposite is **Quiet**, meaning making little or no noise.

questions.question: “Agoshito is a [callow youth]”, said the teacher.
questions.explanation: Callow means inexperienced and immature (naïve). The opposite is **Sophisticated**, meaning having or showing refined knowledge of the world.

questions.question: What you are asking me to do is a [herculean] task.
questions.explanation: Herculean means requiring great strength or effort (difficult, laborious, strenuous). The opposite is **Easy**, meaning achieved without great effort.

questions.question: Nkechi was a [novice] when she was first employed.
questions.explanation: A novice is a person new to or inexperienced in a field or situation (beginner, learner). The opposite is **Expert**, meaning a person who is very knowledgeable about or skilled in a particular area.

questions.question: “ I do not trust him”, he said, in a rare moment of [candour].
questions.explanation: Candour means the quality of being open and honest (frankness, honesty). The opposite is **Deceit**, meaning the action or practice of deceiving someone by concealing or misrepresenting the truth.

questions.question: Mrs. Akunilo looks [anaemic] today.
questions.explanation: Anaemic means lacking in colour, spirit, or vitality (sick, weak). The opposite is **Strong**, meaning powerful, robust, or vigorous.

questions.question: It is [inconceivable] that the sun shone in the night.
questions.explanation: Inconceivable means not capable of being imagined or grasped mentally; unbelievable (unthinkable, impossible). The opposite is **Credible**, meaning able to be believed; convincing.

questions.question: She only gives a [superficial] impression of warmth and friendliness.
questions.explanation: Superficial means existing or occurring at or on the surface; not profound or thorough (fake, unrealistic). The opposite is **a deep** impression, meaning profound or thorough.

questions.question: As a [prudent] businessman, Adayi does leave anything to chance.
questions.explanation: Prudent means acting with or showing care and thought for the future (frugal, shrewd). The opposite is **careless**, meaning not giving sufficient attention or thought to avoiding harm or errors.

questions.question: His [antipathy] affected the growth of his business.
questions.explanation: Antipathy means a deep-seated feeling of dislike; aversion (hatred, hostility). The opposite is **Receptiveness**, meaning open to new ideas or suggestions, which suggests a positive outlook and acceptance.

questions.question: All his plans [fell through].
questions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'fell through' refers to a plan or agreement that failed to happen. The context requires a synonym for failure. 'Failed' is the most accurate and direct option for the meaning of the highlighted phrase.

questions.question: He was appointed specifically to [put the recruits through].
questions.explanation: To 'put someone through' something, especially a group like 'recruits', means to provide them with the necessary course, process, or preparation. The function of a new recruit is to learn, making 'train them' the correct interpretation of the phrasal verb's function here.

questions.question: The result of his experiment represents a [breakthrough] in medical science.
questions.explanation: A 'breakthrough' is defined as a sudden, dramatic, and important development. You must find the option that is a positive and significant event. 'An outstanding success' is the best fit, as the other options suggest failure or conclusion.

questions.question: The State Government appointed a Commission of inquiry to [go into] the community's complaints carefully and without prejudice.
questions.explanation: When an official body like a 'Commission of inquiry' is tasked with addressing issues, the action is thorough and formal. To 'go into' something means to examine, discuss, or investigate it thoroughly. 'Investigate' is the formal synonym that fits the context.

questions.question: The traffic situation in Lagos can lead to disastrous consequences; a man lost a very lucrative job because he was [held up] by it.
questions.explanation: The context is traffic, which prevents movement and causes lateness, resulting in the loss of a job. 'To be held up' in this scenario means 'to be delayed'. This consequence directly links the traffic to the disastrous result.

questions.question: The bridge connecting the two cities was _________ by the enemy.
questions.explanation: The context is military action against a bridge. The phrasal verb for 'destroying something with an explosion' is 'blow up'. The sentence requires this phrasal verb in the passive voice, 'was blown up'.

questions.question: The project which seemed very near realization _________ because of lack of funds.
questions.explanation: The phrase 'because of lack of funds' indicates the project failed. The correct phrasal verb meaning 'to fail to happen' when discussing plans or projects is 'fall through'. The past tense required to fit the sentence is 'fell through'.

questions.question: There is an obvious need to ward _________ enemy attacks.
questions.explanation: This tests knowledge of a fixed phrasal verb. The verb 'ward' combines with the particle 'off' to mean 'to repel or keep away'. 'Ward off' is the standard usage.

questions.question: I didn't think she could be so easily [taken in] by his pretences.
questions.explanation: The key context word is 'pretences' (false shows or appearances). To be 'taken in' means to be tricked or fooled. 'Deceived' is the clearest synonym for this act of trickery.

questions.question: After completing half of the journey, all the travellers could do was [trudge along].
questions.explanation: The context 'After completing half of the journey' suggests the travelers are exhausted. The verb 'trudge' means to walk slowly and heavily, typically due to tiredness. 'Walk wearily' is the best interpretation of this meaning.

questions.question: The clerk refused to [answer for] the mistakes made by the Manager and his assistants.
questions.explanation: To 'answer for' a mistake means to be held accountable or responsible for it. 'To accept responsibility for' captures the core meaning required by the context (mistakes).

questions.question: The Principal will be going away on leave. In his absence, the Vice-Principal will _________ the school.
questions.explanation: When one person replaces another temporarily in a role, they are responsible for the daily duties. 'Look after' means to take care of or be responsible for someone or something, making it the appropriate choice for managing the school in the Principal's absence.

questions.question: The new leader has good intentions, but he is unable to _________ them.
questions.explanation: The object is 'intentions' or plans. The idiom for executing or performing a plan is 'to carry out'. The sentence structure requires the complete phrasal verb 'carry out' with the object pronoun 'them' inserted.

questions.question: In 1996, the Military _________ because of the tragic failure of the civilian politicians.
questions.explanation: The standard idiomatic expression used to describe the act of seizing or gaining governmental control is 'came to power'. Other options are awkward or grammatically incorrect.

questions.question: Why does flamingo stand on one leg? Because if it lifted the other one, it would _________.
questions.explanation: The physical action of losing balance and collapsing to the ground is 'fall down'. This is a direct test of the most appropriate phrasal verb for losing balance.

questions.question: I am travelling by 6:30 train tomorrow morning. Will you _________ me _________?
questions.explanation: The phrasal verb for accompanying a person to their departure point (train, airport) is 'see off'. The first blank takes the verb 'see' and the second takes the particle 'off'.

questions.question: You have been absent from classes for four months. How can you _________ for the lost time?
questions.explanation: The context is about compensating for a period of absence ('lost time'). The correct phrasal verb is 'make up for', meaning to compensate for or remedy something. The particle 'up' is required here.

questions.question: While the mother and father were arguing furiously their small boy sat patiently [taking in] everything they said.
questions.explanation: When discussing spoken words or information, to 'take in' means to understand and mentally retain or absorb. 'Absorbing' is the best synonym for the mental process described.

questions.question: As a result of the injury sustained on the football field, Segun was _________ with a broken leg for months.
questions.explanation: The broken leg confines Segun. The phrasal verb 'lay up' means to be confined to bed or home due to illness or injury. The passive voice form requires 'laid up'.

questions.question: They tried to cash in _________ the people's ignorance.
questions.explanation: The fixed phrasal verb 'cash in on' means to take advantage of something (in this case, ignorance) for profit or gain. The correct preposition is 'on'.

questions.question: After weeks of bargaining they _________ a deal worth millions.
questions.explanation: The context of 'bargaining' and 'millions' suggests they successfully concluded a large deal. To 'bring off' a deal means to succeed in achieving it. 'Brought off' is the past tense form that fits the blank.

questions.question: Maimuna wrote to ask if I could put her _________ for the night.
questions.explanation: To 'put someone up' means to provide them with temporary accommodation or lodging, usually for a short time like 'for the night'. The correct particle is 'up'.

questions.question: He used his savings to [bring up] his nephew.
questions.explanation: To 'bring up' a child is to raise and care for them until they are grown, which encompasses financial provision. While 'feed' is part of it, 'support' is the most complete synonym for the responsibility of raising a relative.

questions.question: You can never get _________ with stealing the presidential jet. You will be caught.
questions.explanation: To 'get away with' a crime means to escape punishment for it. The sentence confirms this meaning by saying 'You will be caught'. The correct particle to form the phrasal verb is 'away'.

questions.question: Always remember to _________ the lights before leaving the room.
questions.explanation: For an electric light, the conventional phrasal verb for turning off the power is 'switch off'. 'Put out' is used for flames or fires. The redundant option has been replaced by 'turn out'.

questions.question: His English was so good that he _________ for an Englishman.
questions.explanation: The phrasal verb is 'take for', meaning to mistake someone for another. The context describes a past condition (his English 'was' good) leading to the passive consequence of being mistaken for an Englishman. The passive past tense, 'was taken', is required.

questions.question: Put _________ your watch, it is half an hour fast.
questions.explanation: Since the watch is 'fast', the user must adjust the time to an earlier setting. The phrasal verb for setting the time earlier is 'put back'.

questions.question: Plans for a rise in production _________ through when a strike started.
questions.explanation: The key is the word 'through' following the blank. The strike caused the plans to fail. The phrasal verb 'fall through' (meaning to fail) requires the past tense verb 'fell' to complete 'fell through' in this context.

questions.question: She used to be very untidy but she has grown _________ it now.
questions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'grow out of' means to stop a habit or preference as one matures or gets older. The context of stopping being 'untidy' fits this meaning, requiring the prepositions 'out of'.

questions.question: Two ministers found it very difficult to get _________ in the Cabinet.
questions.explanation: The verb 'get' is about their relationship. The correct phrasal verb for having a harmonious or friendly relationship is 'get on with'. The sentence requires the reciprocal object and the correct particles: 'get on with each other'.

questions.question: The Head of Department is away to Murtala Mohammed Airport and has asked Dr. Haruna to stand _________ for him.
questions.explanation: The context is substitution. The phrasal verb 'stand in for' means to take someone's place or act as a substitute. The correct particle is 'in'.

questions.question: I do not want the light in my room _________ when I am asleep.
questions.explanation: The structure 'I do not want X done' requires a passive participle. Both 'turned off' and 'turned out' mean to switch off a light. 'Turned out' is a correct and common phrasal verb for switching off a light.

questions.question: To [beat down] the price is to
questions.explanation: To 'beat down' a price is an idiom that refers to negotiating forcefully to get a lower cost. The closest meaning is 'reduce the price'.

questions.question: To [ask after] a friend is to
questions.explanation: The fixed phrasal verb 'ask after' means to inquire about someone's health or general well-being. 'Inquire about the friend's welfare' is the most accurate synonym.

questions.question: To [put something aside] is to
options: put it in a side pocket for future use
keep something for some special purpose
questions.explanation: To 'put aside' means to save or reserve something (like money or time) for future use. 'Keep something for some special purpose' best captures this intention of reserving an item for a specific later date.

questions.question: The thought of his admission to the University [keyed Olu up] to a state of great excitement.
questions.explanation: To 'key someone up' means to make them feel very excited, nervous, or stimulated. Since the context is 'great excitement', 'stimulated Olu' is the best synonym for the effect of the news.

questions.question: What do you want me to do now? I'm _________ withdrawing and keeping quiet.
questions.explanation: The speaker is expressing a preference or support for a course of action. To be 'for' something means to support or be in favor of it. This preposition is required to complete the meaning.

questions.question: I am looking _________ seeing your family.
questions.explanation: The fixed phrasal verb is 'look forward to', meaning to anticipate something with pleasure. It is always followed by a noun or a gerund (as 'seeing' is here). The particles 'forward to' are required.

questions.question: These folktales have been handed _________ from generation to generation.
questions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'hand down' refers to passing traditions, stories, or knowledge from an older generation to a younger one. The context dictates the particle 'down'.

questions.question: While the worshippers closed their eyes in prayer, a thief made _________ with the collection.
questions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'make away with' means to steal something and escape with it. The context of a thief and a collection confirms this meaning. The particle 'away' is required.

questions.question: Children's clothes have to be strong to stand _________ rough use.
questions.explanation: To 'stand up to' something means to resist or endure it without damage. The clothes must endure 'rough use', so the full phrasal verb 'stand up to' is required.

questions.question: The young man looked carefully at the long document, but he couldn't make _________ what it meant.
questions.explanation: To 'make out' a meaning, a word, or a sight means to discern, see, or understand it. The context is about understanding a 'long document', requiring the particle 'out'.

questions.question: Omeime was taking his dog for a walk when the dog suddenly _________ from its chain and escaped.
questions.explanation: The context is escaping from restraint ('its chain'). The correct phrasal verb is 'break loose' (or 'broke loose' in the past tense), meaning to free oneself from restraint. Note that 'loose' is the adjective, not 'lose'.

questions.question: Bankole was a man [given to] much wine.
questions.explanation: To be 'given to' a negative habit (like excessive drinking) means to be habitually inclined or addicted to it. 'Addicted to' is the most accurate synonym for this fixed expression.

questions.question: The officer refused to be [taken in] by the private.
questions.explanation: To be 'taken in' means to be tricked or deceived. The context implies the private was trying to fool the officer. 'Deceived' is the direct meaning.

questions.question: The principal advised that we pursue this case cautiously, otherwise we are bound to be taken _________ by Ada's lies.
questions.explanation: The context is deception ('Ada's lies'). The phrasal verb is 'take in', meaning to deceive or trick. The passive form 'be taken in' requires the particle 'in'.

questions.question: The old politicians were discredited because they tried to _________ the people's ignorance.
questions.explanation: The idiom for exploiting a situation or person for one's own gain is 'cash in on'. This requires the verb 'cash' and the preposition 'on'. The context of using 'ignorance' for political gain confirms this exploitative meaning.

questions.question: He was [locked up] for a fortnight.
questions.explanation: To be 'locked up' means to be confined or imprisoned. In a legal context, being held in custody for a short period, like a 'fortnight' (two weeks), often means being 'remanded', which is the technical legal term for holding someone in custody pending a further hearing or trial. It is the most specific and contextually deep synonym.

questions.question: Olu promised to [look out for] her next time he is in town.
questions.explanation: To 'look out for' someone in the context of being 'in town' implies searching for them with the intention to meet. 'Visit' captures the intended action of meeting a friend in a new location, which is a strong interpretation of the phrase in this personal context.

questions.question: The new educational system [took off] this school year.
questions.explanation: When referring to a plan, project, or career, 'take off' means to start, launch, or become successfully established. The simplest and most direct synonym in the context of the school year is 'began'. Option B ('commenced') is also a close synonym, but 'began' is the most direct common replacement.

verb and tenses.name: Verb and Tenses
verb and tenses.category: Parts of Speech: Verb and Tenses

questions.question: The primary cause of all these accidents __________ driver negligence.
questions.rule_focus: Basic Rule (Singular Subject with Intervening Phrase)
questions.explanation: The real subject is **'cause'** (singular). We ignore the phrase 'of all these accidents'. A singular subject needs a singular verb: **is**.

questions.question: The students in the advanced class __________ preparing for the final presentation.
questions.explanation: The main subject is **'students'** (plural). A plural subject needs a plural verb: **are**.

questions.question: An excellent display of traditional masks and crafts __________ arranged in the main hall.
questions.explanation: The action is about the **'display'** (singular), not the 'masks and crafts'. We ignore the phrase 'of...'. The singular verb **is** is correct.

questions.question: The journalist, as well as the camera crew, __________ arriving at the scene shortly.
questions.explanation: Phrases like 'as well as' don't change the subject count. The verb agrees only with the first subject, **'The journalist'** (singular). Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Our competitors, and not our own team, __________ benefited from the regulatory change.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the subject that is *not* crossed out, which is **'Our competitors'** (plural). The plural verb **have** is correct.

questions.question: The ship, with all its passengers and cargo, __________ heading for the open sea.
questions.explanation: The phrase 'with all its passengers...' is extra information. The main subject is **'The ship'** (singular). Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Neither the coach nor the players __________ prepared for the championship.
questions.explanation: When using 'neither... nor', the verb must agree with the subject that is **closest to it**: **'the players'** (plural). Use the plural verb **were**.

questions.question: Either the committee members or the chairman __________ to approve the final budget.
questions.explanation: When using 'either... or', the verb must agree with the subject **closest to it**: **'the chairman'** (singular). Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Not only the main hall but also the offices __________ in need of urgent renovation.
questions.rule_focus: Correlative Conjunctions (Not only... but also - Plural proximity)
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the closest subject, **'the offices'** (plural). Use the plural verb **are**.

questions.question: Both the marketing team and the sales director __________ agreed on the strategy.
questions.explanation: The structure **'Both... and'** always joins two things, making the subject plural. Use the plural verb **have**.

questions.question: If I am not going, then my brother or my sisters __________ going.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the subject closest to it, **'my sisters'** (plural). Use the plural verb **are**.

questions.question: Either the workers or the manager __________ to take responsibility for the error.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the subject closest to it, **'the manager'** (singular). Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Each of the candidates __________ submitted a detailed proposal.
questions.explanation: Indefinite pronouns like **'Each'**, 'Every', 'Anyone', 'Nobody', etc., are always singular. Ignore 'of the candidates'. Use the singular verb **has**.

questions.question: Every seat and every aisle in the theater __________ been checked for safety.
questions.explanation: The word **'Every'** forces the whole subject (seat and aisle) to be treated as singular. Use the singular verb **has**.

questions.question: Everyone who completed the assignment __________ eligible for extra credit.
questions.explanation: The indefinite pronoun **'Everyone'** is always singular. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Nobody in the surrounding villages __________ seen anything unusual.
questions.explanation: The indefinite pronoun **'Nobody'** is always singular. Use the singular verb **has**.

questions.question: Several of the items on the menu __________ changed since last year.
questions.explanation: Indefinite pronouns like **'Several'**, 'Both', 'Few', and 'Many' are always plural. Use the plural verb **have**.

questions.question: Many a candidate __________ the true meaning of the party's manifesto.
questions.explanation: The phrase **'Many a'** is an exception and always requires a singular noun and a **singular verb**: **fails to grasp**.

questions.question: Neither of the two solutions __________ completely satisfactory.
questions.explanation: The indefinite pronoun **'Neither'** is always singular. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: The whole cast of the play __________ travelling together on the bus.
questions.explanation: A collective noun like **'cast'** is treated as one single unit when the group acts together. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: The jury __________ still deliberating on the verdict.
questions.explanation: The collective noun **'jury'** is typically treated as a singular unit when acting together (deliberating one verdict). Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: The board of directors __________ unable to agree on a single course of action.
questions.explanation: The verb **were** is used because the members of the **'board'** are acting individually (they couldn't 'agree'). The focus is on the members, not the unit.

questions.question: Mumps __________ still considered a serious illness for adults.
questions.explanation: Names of diseases that end in 's' (like **'Mumps'**, *measles*) are treated as singular nouns. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Economics __________ often described as the dismal science.
questions.rule_focus: Nouns Plural in Form (Academic Discipline - Singular)
questions.explanation: Academic subjects ending in 's' (like **'Economics'**, *Physics*) are treated as singular nouns. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Five hundred dollars __________ not enough to cover the tuition fee.
questions.explanation: When an amount of money or time (**'Five hundred dollars'**) is seen as a single, fixed unit, it is treated as singular. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: The police __________ arrived at the scene of the accident.
questions.explanation: The word **'police'** is always treated as plural. Use the plural verb **have**.

questions.question: Two-thirds of the employees __________ given a holiday bonus this year.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the noun *after* the fraction. **'employees'** is plural, so the verb must be plural: **were**.

questions.question: One-third of the city's infrastructure __________ damaged by the recent flood.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the noun *after* the fraction. **'infrastructure'** is uncountable (singular), so the verb must be singular: **is**.

questions.question: Seventy percent of the club members __________ voted against the new rule.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the noun *after* the percentage. **'club members'** is plural, so the verb must be plural: **have**.

questions.question: Most of the paperwork for the merger __________ completed yesterday.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the noun *after* the quantifier. **'paperwork'** is uncountable (singular), so the verb must be singular: **was**.

questions.question: None of the money collected for the charity __________ yet to be deposited.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the noun *after* 'None of'. **'money'** is uncountable (singular), so the verb must be singular: **is**.

questions.question: All of the computers in the laboratory __________ running the latest software.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the noun *after* 'All of'. **'computers'** is plural, so the verb must be plural: **are**.

questions.question: The laptop and the projector __________ necessary tools for the presentation.
questions.explanation: Two separate things joined by **'and'** (**'laptop'** and **'projector'**) always create a plural subject. Use the plural verb **are**.

questions.question: Bread and butter __________ my favourite meal on Fridays.
questions.explanation: When two subjects joined by 'and' represent a single, fixed idea or dish (**'Bread and butter'**), they take a singular verb. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: The principal and academic director of the school __________ resigned today.
questions.explanation: Since the article **'The'** is only used once (before 'principal'), the sentence refers to one person holding both jobs. Use the singular verb **has**.

questions.question: The novelist and poet, who is also my neighbour, __________ giving a lecture tonight.
questions.explanation: The single use of the article 'The' before **'novelist'** indicates that the subject is one person holding two titles, requiring the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: He is one of the managers who always __________ tasks to subordinates.
questions.explanation: The pronoun 'who' refers to the plural word **'managers'**. Therefore, the verb must be plural: **delegate**.

questions.question: She is the only one of the applicants who __________ all the qualifications.
questions.rule_focus: Relative Pronouns ('The Only One' - Forces Singularity)
questions.explanation: The words **'the only one'** restrict the meaning, forcing the pronoun 'who' to refer to the singular word **'one'**. Use the singular verb **meets**.

questions.question: The ancient carving that __________ in the museum __________ over a thousand years old.
questions.explanation: The main subject **'carving'** is singular. Both the verb in the relative clause and the main verb must be singular: **is displayed/is**.

questions.question: These are the issues that __________ the most attention from the public.
questions.explanation: The relative pronoun 'that' refers to the plural antecedent **'issues'**. The verb must be plural: **deserve**.

questions.question: The decision is one of the important factors that ultimately __________ the project's success.
questions.explanation: The relative pronoun 'that' refers to the plural antecedent **'factors'**. The verb must be plural: **determine**.

questions.question: There __________ only one possible solution to this complex problem.
questions.explanation: In sentences starting with 'There' or 'Here', the verb agrees with the word *following* the blank. The subject is **'one possible solution'** (singular). Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: There __________ several unexpected complications during the surgery.
questions.explanation: The subject is **'several unexpected complications'** (plural). Use the plural verb **were**.

questions.question: Here __________ the keys for your new apartment.
questions.explanation: The subject is **'the keys'** (plural). Use the plural verb **are**.

questions.question: The classic film *Jaws* __________ still terrifying audiences decades later.
questions.explanation: The title of a single work (*Jaws*) is always treated as **singular**, even if the words inside are plural. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: His new book of essays, *Ideas and Paradoxes*, __________ a difficult read for most students.
questions.explanation: The subject is the singular head noun **'book'**. The title, *Ideas and Paradoxes*, is treated as a single unit. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: The phrase 'All is fair in love and war' __________ often misused in casual speech.
questions.explanation: A quoted phrase used as a subject is always treated as a **singular unit**. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: Linguistics __________ the scientific study of language and its structure.
questions.rule_focus: Nouns Plural in Form (Academic Discipline - Singular)
questions.explanation: Academic subjects ending in 's' (**'Linguistics'**) are singular concepts. Use the singular verb **is**.

questions.question: The committee members, not the leader, __________ responsible for the final presentation.
questions.explanation: The verb agrees with the subject that is *not* crossed out, which is **'The committee members'** (plural). Use the plural verb **are**.

questions.question: All the necessary scissors and tweezers __________ packed in the first aid kit.
questions.explanation: Nouns for paired items (**'scissors'** and **'tweezers'**) are always treated as **plural** (like pants or glasses). Use the plural verb **were**.
